ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I learned how to scrutinize ancient Greek as a language itself rather than as just a mode of communicating literary/philosophical ideas. This was also my first experience with academic historical linguistics, despite being a linguistics major, so I learned how to discuss the relationship between a proto language and its daughter language.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: I think the workload for this class could be lowered somewhat. I also think there could be more connection between the work in class and the homework, because it often felt like the two were completely unrelated.

Strengths: the material is fascinating. Because I am both a classics major and a linguistics major, a class which is essentially devoted to the linguistic study of Greek is perfect for me. Feedback is very clear on all the homework assignments as well, thanks to our great TF, Maria.
Weaknesses: all this being said, I do not know how I could have approached this course without my linguistics background. This class implicitly has a lot of prerequisite knowledge: we are plunged into morphophonological analyses, so it is very helpful to have a background in linguistics, and, more crucially, we discuss the style and dialect variations of different authors, so it is really crucial to be quite well-read to get the most out of this class. This was my first L5 Greek class; in reality, it should be your last.
Whether or not this class should be required for Greek majors is questionable: it is supposed to be analogous to LATN 390, but it also deals heavily with Indo-European linguistics rather than being focused solely on composition; in fact, composition is the LEAST fleshed-out of the course's three parts, since we only do composition as homework. Now, I still find this class absolutely enthralling, but this is because of my specialized interests. The information in the class is valuable to undergrad majors, but often it feels like it is on the graduate level.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: I would recommend this course to another student, on the caveat that they have already taken some L5 Greek classes and are familiar with the dialect and stylistic variations between different authors. I would also be alert of how linguistically-heavy this class will be; it is fascinating but can be jarring at first if you do not have any background in linguistics.
